Charming, handsome, irreverent, tenacious and an outstanding 
talent, James Hunt had everything it took to become one of 
EnglandÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s most famous sportsmen and a household. However, it 
was his dogged determination and epic battles with Niki Lauda 
which made him a Grand Prix Hero.

Glorious archive footage shows us the great racer in action, 
while rare interviews remind us of the cheeky quips and 
trademark broad grin. ThereÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s dramatic racing film from his 
debut at the 1973 Monaco Grand Prix right through to the 
Formula One World Championship-decided Japanese Grand Prix in 
1976, with narration throughout from Sir Stirling Moss.

Despite a reputation which earned him the nickname Ã¢â‚¬ËœHunt the 
ShuntÃ¢â‚¬â„¢, Lord Hesketh signed up the young Brit for an assault 
on Formula One. We are treated to footage from that first 
year, including HuntÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s maiden podium at the Dutch Grand Prix, 
and action from 1974, when Hunt, with Harvey PostlethwaiteÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s 
Hesketh 308 at his disposal could manage only three podium 
finishes. The 1975 season also proved tough for the team, but 
the highlight came at Zandvoort when Hunt scored his first, 
and HeskethÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s only, Grand Prix win Ã¢â‚¬â€œ and archive footage lets 
us share the epic battle with Lauda.

In 1976 came a move to McLaren and one of the most fascinating 
and turbulent seasonÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s of Formula One racing. LaudaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Ferrari 
led the way with a domination which would have broken the spirit 
of most contenders. Not Hunt. Neither was his ambition stifled 
by controversies such as disqualification from two GP wins or a 
grid penalty Ã¢â‚¬ËœmistakeÃ¢â‚¬â„¢. Hunt kept the pressure on and at the 
final race of the year he was just 3 points behind Lauda, still
carrying the scars of his horrific crash in Germany.

Some say Hunt won his World Championship be default, due to 
LaudaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s crash, but the spectacular and determined racing in this 
DVD shows he was a worthy winner, and a true Grand Prix Hero
